title: Slasher Database Errors (MapFull)
body:
## Description

Beacon Node throwing errors about slasher service and pruning of slasher database

## Version

Docker image `v1.5.0` (I also saw this in `v1.4.0`)

## Present Behaviour

I get a steady stream of errors related to the slasher service:
```
Aug 24 20:48:11.729 ERRO Error during slasher database pruning   error: DatabaseError(MapFull), epoch: 59979, service: slasher
Aug 24 20:48:25.437 ERRO Error processing array update           error: DatabaseError(MapFull), service: slasher
Aug 24 20:48:25.441 ERRO Error during scheduled slasher processing, error: DatabaseError(MapFull), epoch: 59979, service: slasher
...
Aug 24 20:48:50.141 ERRO Error during slasher database pruning   error: DatabaseError(MapFull), epoch: 59979, service: slasher
Aug 24 20:49:04.834 ERRO Error processing array update           error: DatabaseError(MapFull), service: slasher
Aug 24 20:49:04.837 ERRO Error during scheduled slasher processing, error: DatabaseError(MapFull), epoch: 59979, service: slasher
```

## Expected Behaviour

No errors?

## Steps to resolve

I have two servers, both running via docker, both with the same behavior...

Here is my sanitized `docker-compose.yaml` (`<redacted>`)
```
version: "3.4"

services:
  lh-beacon:
    container_name: lh-beacon
    image: "sigp/lighthouse:v1.5.0"
    volumes:
      - "/data/volumes/lh-beacon:/root/.lighthouse"
    ports:
      - "9000:9000" # Peering (TCP)
      - "9000:9000/udp" # Peering (UDP)
    restart: unless-stopped
    command:
      - lighthouse
      - beacon_node
      # FLAGS
      - --disable-upnp
      - --eth1
      - --http
      - --metrics
      - --slasher
      - --subscribe-all-subnets
      - --import-all-attestations
      - --validator-monitor-auto
      # OPTIONS
      - --monitoring-endpoint=<redacted>
      - --eth1-endpoints=<redacted>
      - --http-address=0.0.0.0
      - --http-allow-origin=*
      - --metrics-address=0.0.0.0
      - --metrics-allow-origin=*
      - --network=mainnet
      - --port=9000
      - --target-peers=50
      - --slasher-broadcast
      - --libp2p-addresses=<redacted>
      - --trusted-peers=<redacted>
      - --validator-monitor-pubkeys=<redacted>
    logging:
      driver: "local"
```

This is a really powerful server, plenty of RAM, plenty of disk space. I assume this has something to do with trying to run a slasher subscribed to all subnets or something? I would think this should be a possible setup?

OS is `Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS (GNU/Linux 5.4.0-80-generic x86_64)`

```bash
# docker version
```

Oh and my slasher database is suspiciously almost exactly 256GB lol
```
/data/volumes/lh-beacon/mainnet/beacon/slasher_db # ls -al data.mdb 
-rw------- 1 root root 274877890560 Aug 24 20:46 data.mdb
```

Unfortunately this is a known issue, particularly when subscribed to all subnets (see https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse/issues/2112).

For now the solution is to either bump up the max database size, or delete the database and start again. There's a rough formula for determining the size to set [here](https://lighthouse-book.sigmaprime.io/slasher.html#max-database-size). Unfortunately the 256GB default hasn't been updated since we surpassed 150K validators. I also suspect the formula could do with an extra factor of 2 for the way LMDB handles multi-version concurrency control. Plugging in 300K validators with a 2x overhead yields 884GB, which is a bit obscene. If you want to start again you can just `rm -rf $datadir/beacon/slasher_db` while the node is stopped.

We have a plan to cut the storage requirements down a lot in https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse/issues/2286, but we haven't had a chance to start implementing it between everything else going on (Altair, merge, validator optimisations, etc).

Alright! Thanks, I think for now I'll just increase the `- --slasher-max-db-size` and see how that goes :eagle: :eyes:

I'll keep track of these issues as well. Much appreciated the quick reply.
Noting here that this can manifest as really high disk read rates (on the order of 70MB/s). I'm not exactly sure _why_ that is the failure mode, but it's worth documenting.
